comments.content:
C is the correct answer kid
A docking station is a hardware accessory that allows laptops to connect to multiple peripherals and devices with a single connection. A docking station with DisplayPort would provide the necessary connectivity for the dual monitors, and it can also support the required peripherals such as the keyboard, mouse, and speakers. In addition, it will provide a wired network connectivity for faster and more reliable network access.

I don't know what docking stations you have used, but the ones I install are single power source. The docking station is powered through the wall and it provides power to the laptop. It would be silly to have your laptop plugged into a docking station and also plug it into the power supply.

On the other hand, a USB hub can get dual monitors through the USB-C but I don't believe they offer wired network connectivity.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The BEST accessory to meet the new user's needs would be a docking station with DisplayPort. A docking station provides a single connection point for multiple peripherals, including a keyboard, mouse, speakers, and dual monitors, while also providing power to the laptop. DisplayPort is a popular video connector that supports high-resolution displays and can handle dual monitors. A PoE switch provides power to network-connected devices and would not support keyboard, mouse, speakers, or dual monitors. A USB-C hub with power delivery can support a keyboard, mouse, and speakers but may not support dual monitors. A KVM switch with audio would allow the user to switch between multiple computers and peripherals, but it would not support power delivery or dual monitors.

Selected Answer: C
I'm confident that C is the best choice to meet the new user's needs. It provides a single connection point for the laptop, supports various peripherals, including dual monitors, and typically includes power delivery and wired network connectivity features.

questions.question_text: A new employee has been issued a company laptop. The employee requests an accessory with a single power source that has wired network connectivity and supports a keyboard, mouse, speakers, and dual monitors. Which of the following accessories should the systems administrator deploy to BEST meet the new user's needs?

choices.C: Switches receive data and route it to all computers inside the network, while hubs receive data and do not route.
choices.D: Switches scramble data, while hubs send data in the original form.
choices.A: Switches only send data to the specific computer, while hubs send data to all computers inside the network.
choices.B: Switches compress data, while hubs send uncompressed data.

questions.question_text: Which of the following describes the operational difference between hubs and switches when transmitting data to a specific computer inside the network?

comments.content:
https://www.examtopics.com/exams/comptia/220-1101/view/23/
not be opend plz guide me

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. Switches only send data to the specific computer, while hubs send data to all computers inside the network.

Switches operate on the data link layer of the OSI model and are designed to send data only to the specific computer that is intended to receive it, based on the computer's media access control (MAC) address. This makes network communication more efficient and secure. In contrast, hubs operate at the physical layer of the OSI model and simply broadcast all data to all connected computers, which can lead to network congestion and security issues.

Selected Answer: A
Because that hubs operate at OSI Layer 1 and switches operate at OSI Layer 2, the hub sends all traffic to all hosts connected to the hub. Hubs only run in half-duplex meaning it can only send and receive traffic one at a time. Switches in the other hand floods out its port except the given VLAN. While hubs create more collision domains, switches divides out collision domains and increases broadcast domains. Switches can run in either full, or half duplex.

Selected Answer: A
. In effect, the computers seem to be attached to the same cable. Each computer attached to a hub receives all the traffic sent by other connected devices. This is referred to as a "collision domain." . Unlike a hub, an Ethernet switch can decode each frame and identify the source and destination MAC addresses. It can track which MAC source addresses are associated with each port. Switch forward the incoming frame to the port that matches the physical address of the device ( MAC address ). CompTIA Learn CertMaster

questions.question_text: Which of the following network devices would an administrator use to distribute traffic evenly throughout multiple nodes?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The load balancer is used to move or distribute client network requests from the internet across the same type of servers. When one of the servers is overwhelmed then the load balancer is moving it to another the same type of server. It makes sure that traffic does not overwhelm any of the servers by balanced distribution. Bridges are used to connect two or more networks together; a firewall filters traffic using ACL to allow or block certain computers. Proxy servers can also filter, modify, and provide caching services. It reduces bandwidth consumption and improves network performance. Switch handling network requests between ISP or router to physical devices on the network. I think Load Balancer would be correct

Selected Answer: A
This is a tricky one, if the guy was following all the correct steps changing the GPU and drivers should have been one of the later solutions. It makes sense to check cabling first, then test a new monitor, then replace gpu. I guess if he neglected to check cabling that would be the correct answer. Plus color hues are a common symptom of VGA cables not being plugged in correctly/damaged.

A is the correct answer
The pink hue is most likely caused by physical cabling issues
the output on a monitor is clear but has a pink hue, it could be due to an issue with the physical cabling connecting the monitor to the computer. The video signal may be degraded or distorted due to a damaged or loose cable. The technician should check and replace the cable if necessary to resolve the issue.

From Intel website:
Article describing solution for when pink screen is shown when using the system-
Check that the video cable is firmly connected to the display and to the system. A loose connection can result in discoloration.
Try a different video cable to connect the system to the monitor. The video cable can be damaged or faulty.

Selected Answer: C
The answer is C, display burn-in.

Burn-in is a phenomenon that occurs when a static image is displayed on a monitor for an extended period of time. The image can become permanently etched into the monitor's screen, resulting in a pink hue.

The other options are not as likely.

Physical cabling issues (A) can cause problems with the output of a monitor, but they are not likely to cause a pink hue.
Burned-out bulb (B) is a possibility, but it is less likely than display burn-in.
Incorrect data source (D) is not likely to cause a pink hue.

comments.content: What modern monitors use bulbs? That is TV technology not monitors. Monitors commonly use LED

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Burned-out bulb is the most likely cause of a clear monitor output with a pink hue. When the bulb or backlight of a monitor goes bad, it can cause a pink or reddish tint to the image.

Selected Answer: A
The most likely cause of the pink hue on the monitor is a physical cabling issue. A pink hue can be caused by poor cable connectivity, a damaged cable, or incorrect cable type used. The video card and graphics drivers have already been updated and replaced, which eliminates them as potential causes. Display burn-in occurs over a prolonged period of time, whereas this issue is happening immediately. Incorrect data source can cause display issues, but is unlikely to cause a specific hue like pink. A burned-out bulb can cause color issues but would likely result in a complete loss of display, not just a hue change.
